newsitem.title: UK: Most British firms unconcerned by minimum wage - survey.
newsitem.headline: Most British firms unconcerned by minimum wage - survey.

text.p: Almost four fifths of British businesses believe a national minimum wage would have no damaging impact if it were set at 3.75 pounds ($5.97) an hour, a survey said on Monday.
Reed Personnel Services, a recruitment specialist, said 79 percent of the 969 firms surveyed said business would not suffer from minimum wage legislation set at that level.
The opposition Labour party has committed itself to introducting a minimum wage if it wins power in the election, due to be held by May.
It has not yet suggested a level, but plans to take advice from a low new pay commission which will include employers' and employees' representatives.
However, even if the minimum wage were set at a higher level, a majority of firms said they would still be unaffected.
If the rate were set at 3.50 pounds, 76 percent of firms said it would not be a problem, although the remaining 19 percent said their business would suffer.
Even at 4.0 pounds per hour, 63 percent of firms said there business would not be damaged.
"The great majority of UK businesses predict they would be unaffected by a National Minimum Wage," said Alec Reed, chairman of Reed Personnel Services.
"However, the report shows it would be important for any future implementation to be handled carefully, and not railroaded though."
He said in particular, the worries of those businesses who feel they have most to lose should be carefully addressed.
The Labour Party welcomed the findings.
"This survey has nailed the Tory lie that a minimum wage is bad for business," said Labour's chief employment spokesman Ian McCartney. ($ = 0.627 British Pounds)
